src:
Plameni pogoltnili dragocen spomenik
Grad, del Unescove svetovne dediščine, je uničen. Več kot 100 gasilcev se je okoli 12 ur borilo z ognjem.
03 Nov 2019, 16:56 by A. J.



REUTERSOd veličastne zgradbe, ki ima za Okinavce poseben pomen, je ostalo bore malo. fotografiji: REUTERS



REUTERSDomačini so, nekateri v v solzah, opazovali, kako simbol mesta pred njihovimi očmi izginja v ognju.


NAHA – V četrtek zgodaj zjutraj, okoli 2.40 po lokalnem času, je izbruhnil ogenj v zgodovinskem gradu Šuri na japonskem južnem otoku Okinava in skoraj popolnoma uničil zgradbo, ki je del Unescove svetovne dediščine in priljubljena turistična točka. Več kot sto gasilcev se je borilo s plameni okoli 12 ur, preden jim jih je popoldne okoli 13.30 uspelo ukrotiti. Ogenj v Nahi, glavnem mestu Okinave, se je začel v osrednjem delu pretežno lesenega gradu in se hitro razširil na preostale zgradbe, saj je bil dan precej vetroven. Tri velike dvorane in štiri druge zgradbe so pogorele do tal. Ranjenih ni bilo.Teden dni trajajoč festival, ki se je začel v nedeljo, bi se moral odvijati ves teden, vendar so dogodke odpovedali. Organizatorji so pripravljali grad na dogajanje naslednjega dne še do malce čez polnoč, ko pa je začelo goreti, ni bilo tam nikogar več. Oranžni plameni so pogoltnili glavno stavbo, od katere je ostalo le še leseno ogrodje. Številni prebivalci glavnega mesta so opazovali tragično spreminjanje dragocenega kulturnega spomenika v pepel, nekateri so jokali. »Menim, da smo izgubili simbol mesta. Šokiran sem,« je komentiral župan Nahe Mikiko Široma. Guverner Okinave Deni Tamaki, ki se je ravno vrnil z obiska v Južni Koreji, je dejal, da je njegovo srce strto, da pa meni, da morajo grad, ki je simbol kraljevine Rjukju ter kulturni in zgodovinski spomenik, vsekakor obnoviti.


Domačini so, nekateri v v solzah, opazovali, kako simbol mesta pred njihovimi očmi izginja v ognju.REUTERS

Pred petsto leti zgrajeni grad je simbol Okinave in kraljevine Rjukju, ki je vladala med letoma 1429 in 1979, ko se je otok priključil Japonski. Je tudi simbol truda Okinavcev, da bi se po drugi svetovni vojni postavili na noge. Do tal je bil požgan tik pred koncem vojne, leta 1945 v bitki za Okinavo, v kateri je življenje izgubilo 200.000 ljudi, med njimi mnogi civilisti. Leta 1992 so ga obnovili, postal je nacionalni park, leta 2000 pa del Unescove svetovne dediščine. 
1992.leta so grad obnovili.
text:
Flames swallowed up a valuable monument
The castle, part of the UNESCO World Heritage Site, is destroyed. More than 100 firefighters fought the blaze for about 12 hours.
03 Nov 2019, 15:56 by A.J.



REUTERSO Of the magnificent building, which has a special meaning for the Okinawa, there is little fight left. photos by REUTERS



REUTERSHome people, some in tears, watched the symbol of the city disappear in the fire before their eyes.


NAHA - A fire broke out early Thursday morning at about 2.40 local time in the historic Shuri Castle on Japan's southern Okinawa Island, destroying the UNESCO World Heritage Site and popular tourist spot almost completely. More than a hundred firefighters battled the blaze for about 12 hours before managing to tame them at around 1.30pm. The fire in Naha, the capital of Okinawa, started in the central part of a mostly wooden castle and quickly spread to the rest of the buildings as the day was quite windy. Three large halls and four other buildings burned to the ground. There were no injuries. The week-long festival, which began on Sunday, should have taken place throughout the week, but the events were canceled. The organizers were preparing the castle for the next day until midnight, but when it started to burn, there was no one else there. Orange flames swallowed the main building, of which only a wooden frame remained. Many residents of the capital saw the tragic turning of a valuable cultural monument into ashes, some crying. “I think we have lost the symbol of the city. I am shocked, "commented Nahe Mayor Mikiko Shiroma. Okinawa Governor Deni Tamaki, who had just returned from a visit to South Korea, said his heart was broken but thought the castle, a symbol of the Rjukju kingdom and a cultural and historical monument, should be restored.


Locals, some in tears, watched the symbol of the city disappear in the fire before their eyes.REUTERS

Five hundred years ago, the castle built was a symbol of Okinawa and the Ryukyu Kingdom, which ruled between 1429 and 1979 when the island annexed Japan. It is also a symbol of the efforts of the Okinawa to get back on their feet after World War II. It was burnt to the ground just before the end of the war, in 1945 in the Battle of Okinawa, in which 200,000 people lost their lives, many civilians, among them. It was rebuilt in 1992, became a national park and in 2000 a part of UNESCO World Heritage.
In 1992 the castle was rebuilt.
